heading: üß¨ Welcome to genekitr!
text: book tutorial gene information query, gene identifier conversion, gene enrichment analysis, publication-level plotting. new R, worry, set enough example codes guide book. reading book, plot figures based analysis result.

heading: üç± Content
text: Part 1 (Search Information) introduces search gene metadata PubMed papers.Part 2 (ID Conversion) describes ID conversion among symbol & alias, NCBI Entrez, Ensembl, Uniprot microarray probe.Part 3 (Enrichment Analysis) describes two widely used functional enrichment methods -representation analysis (ORA) functional class scoring (FCS).Part 4 (Plotting) includes 14 GO plots, 7 KEGG plots, 5 GSEA plots, 2 Venn plots, 1 Volcano plot.

heading: üíù Welcome to contribute
text: Book source code https://github.com/GangLiLab/book_genekitr.get ideas issues, please feel free post feedback.

heading: 1 Quick start
text: part helps users quickly go function usage. Click title view details.

heading: 1.1 Search gene metadata
code:
id <- c("MCM10", "CDC20", "S100A9", "MMP1", "BCC7","FAKEID","HBD", "NUDT10")
info <- genInfo(id, org = "hs")
# keep unique records
info2 <- genInfo(id, org = "hs", unique = TRUE)

heading: 1.2 Search PubMed records
code:
## check package version
packageVersion("genekitr")

## for version < 0.8.6
term <- c("Tp53", "Brca1", "Tet2")
keys <- c("stem cell", "mouse")
l <- getPubmed(term, keys)

## for version > 0.8.6
term <- c("Tp53", "Brca1", "Tet2")
add_term <- c("stem cell", "mouse")
l <- getPubmed(term, add_term, num = 30)

# set "num" larger to get all records
all <- getPubmed(term, add_term, num = 666666)

heading: 1.3 Gene ID conversion
code:
id <-  c("Cyp2c23", "Fhit", "Gal3st2b", "Trp53", "Tp53")
sym2ens <- transId(id ,transTo = "ensembl", org = "mouse")
# keep unique records
sym2ensent <- transId(id ,transTo = c("ensembl","entrez"), org = "mouse", unique = TRUE)

heading: 1.4 Protein ID conversion
code:
id <-  c("P27364", "P14046", "P15650", "P16638", "P24483")
protein2sym <- transId(id ,transTo = "sym", org = "rat")

heading: 1.5 Probe ID conversion
code:
id <-  c('205647_at','204857_at','201394_s_at','210377_at')
probe2sym <- transProbe(id, transTo = 'sym',org = 'hs')

heading: 1.6 ORA GO analysis
text: ORA stands ‚Äú-representation analysis‚Äù.
code:
id <- c("TP53","BRCA1", "PD1", "PDL1")
ego <- genGO(id,
  org = "human",
  ont = "bp",
  pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
  qvalueCutoff = 0.01
)

heading: 1.7 ORA KEGG analysis
code:
id <- c("TP53","BRCA1", "PD1", "PDL1","BRCA2","TET2")
keg <- genKEGG(id,
  org = "human",
  pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
  qvalueCutoff = 0.05
)

heading: 1.8 ORA human disease analysis
code:
# support `do` (Disease Ontology), `ncg` (Network of Cancer Gene) and `dgn` (DisGeNET)
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
id <- names(geneList)[abs(geneList) > 1]

edo <- genORA(id, type = "do")
encg <- genORA(names(geneList), type = "ncg")
edgn <- genORA(id, type = "dgn", 
               pvalueCutoff = 0.01, 
               qvalueCutoff = 0.01)
ewiki <- genORA(id, type = "wiki", org = "human")

heading: 1.9 FCS GSEA analysis
text: FCS stands ‚Äúfunctional-class-scoring‚Äù.geneList order ranked gene list decreasing order. Gene inside can Entrez, Ensembl symbol.
code:
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
gse <- genGSEA(
  genelist = geneList,
  org = "human",
  category = "H"
)

heading: 1.10.1 Import Panther of GeneOntology website
code:
# here we save panther result as "analysis.txt"
panther_res <- importPanther("analysis.txt")

heading: 1.10.2 Import clusterProfiler result
code:
library(clusterProfiler)
library(org.Hs.eg.db)
data(geneList, package="DOSE")
gene <- names(geneList)[abs(geneList) > 2]

## GO result from clusterProfiler
go <- enrichGO(gene          = gene,
                OrgDb         = org.Hs.eg.db,
                ont           = "BP",
                pAdjustMethod = "BH",
                pvalueCutoff  = 0.01,
                qvalueCutoff  = 0.05)
## GSEA result from clusterProfiler
kk <- gseKEGG(geneList     = geneList,
               organism     = 'hsa',
               minGSSize    = 120,
               pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
               verbose      = FALSE)
## Other ORA result from clusterProfiler 
# (e.g. KEGG/DOSE/WikiPathways...)
do <- enrichDO(gene          = gene,
              ont           = "DO",
              pvalueCutoff  = 0.05,
              pAdjustMethod = "BH",
              universe      = names(geneList),
              minGSSize     = 5,
              maxGSSize     = 500,
              qvalueCutoff  = 0.05)

## Import 
go_easy <- importCP(go, type = "go")
kk_easy <- importCP(kk,type = 'gsea')
do_easy <- importCP(do,type = 'other')

heading: 1.11 Plot GO and KEGG
text:
Supported types include: bar, wego, bubble, dot, lollipop, geneheat, genechord,
network, gomap, goheat, gotangram, wordcloud, upset two-group barplot
code:
plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "dot")
plotEnrich(keg, plot_type = "bar")
plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "geneheat")
plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "network", scale_ratio = 0.5)

heading: 1.12 Plot GSEA
text: Supported types include: volcano, classic, fgsea, ridge bar
code:
plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "volcano", show_pathway = 3)

genes <- c("MET", "TP53", "PMM2")
plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "classic", show_pathway = pathways, show_gene = genes)

plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "fgsea", show_pathway = 3)

heading: 1.13 Plot Venn
code:
set1 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set2 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set3 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))

# classic venn plot
plotVenn(list(gset1 = set1, gset2 = set2, gset3 = set3), use_venn = TRUE)
# UpSet plot
plotVenn(list(gset1 = set1, gset2 = set2, gset3 = set3), use_venn = FALSE)

heading: 1.14 Plot DEG Volcano
code:
data(deg, package = "genekitr")
plotVolcano(deg, "p.adjust",
  remove_legend = T,
  show_gene = c("CD36", "DUSP6", "IER3", "CDH7")
)

heading: 2 Search gene metadata
text: genInfo() function helps user quickly search batch gene metadata names, location, GC content, etc.

heading: 2.1 Supported organisms
text: supports 195 vertebrate species, 120 plant species, two bacteria species. data --date.user select organism name latin_short_name column.common name also acceptable popular research species (e.g., human, mouse, rat, fly, zebrafish, worm, chicken). Take human example, official latin short name ‚Äúhsapiens‚Äù, " hg‚Äú,‚Äùhsa‚Äú,‚Äùhs‚Äú, ‚Äùhuman" also acceptable.
code:
# install.packages('DT')
library(genekitr)
DT::datatable(ensOrg_name, options = list(pageLength = 10))

heading: 2.2 Basic usage
text: genInfo three arguments:id: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idid: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idorg: organism name, default humanorg: organism name, default humanunique: TRUE FALSE. Commonly, one gene many types matched records. example, human HBD gene three matched Entrez IDs: 3045, 85349, 100187828. TRUE, return one--one match result smallest entrezid maximal information (minimal NAs). See example genekitr feature2.unique: TRUE FALSE. Commonly, one gene many types matched records. example, human HBD gene three matched Entrez IDs: 3045, 85349, 100187828. TRUE, return one--one match result smallest entrezid maximal information (minimal NAs). See example genekitr feature2.

id <- c("TP53", "BRCA1", "TET2")

id <- c(
  "MCM10", "CDC20", "S100A9",
  "FAKEID", "TP53", "HBD", "NUDT10"
)
# for human id, no need to input the org argument
info <- genInfo(id, unique = TRUE)
identical(id, info$input_id)## [1] TRUE

heading: 2.3.2 f2: keep unique or not
text: unique = TRUE, one record maximal information returned.
code:
id <- "HBD"
uniq_info <- genInfo(id, org = "hs", unique = TRUE)
uniq_info[, 1:4]##   input_id symbol entrezid         ensembl
## 2      HBD    HBD     3045 ENSG00000223609
all_info <- genInfo(id, org = "hs", unique = FALSE)
all_info[, 1:4]##   input_id symbol  entrezid         ensembl
## 1      HBD    HBD 100187828 ENSG00000223609
## 2      HBD    HBD      3045 ENSG00000223609
## 3      HBD KRT87P     85349 ENSG00000135477

heading: 2.3.3.1 distinguish from gene symbol and alias
text: Many common gene names gene alias, many tools accept gene symbols cause gene information lost. example, ‚ÄúBCC7‚Äù alias ‚ÄúTP53‚Äù ‚ÄúPD1‚Äù three aliases: ‚ÄúPDCD1‚Äù, ‚ÄúSNCA‚Äù ‚ÄúSPATA2‚Äù enrichment analyses tools recognize ‚ÄúBCC7‚Äù.
code:
id <- c("BCC7", "PD1")
genInfo(id)[1:4]##   input_id symbol entrezid         ensembl
## 1     BCC7   TP53     7157 ENSG00000141510
## 2      PD1  PDCD1     5133 ENSG00000276977
## 3      PD1  PDCD1     5133 ENSG00000188389
## 4      PD1   SNCA     6622 ENSG00000145335
## 5      PD1 SPATA2     9825 ENSG00000158480

heading: 2.3.3.2 distinguish gene symbol with special characters
code:
id <- c("TNF-Œ±", "Œ∫B-Ras2")
genInfo(id)[1:4]##   input_id  symbol entrezid         ensembl
## 1    TNF-Œ±     TNF     7124 ENSG00000228978

heading: 3 Search PubMed records
text:
getPubmed function utilizes europepmc easily get PubMed records searching paper abstract.Users need input term argument; supplement information, keys parameter available.example, user wants check papers genes ‚ÄúTp53‚Äù, ‚ÄúBrca1,‚Äù ‚ÄúTet2‚Äù research mouse stem cells:NOTICE:
minor update made version 0.8.6 . Argument keys replaced add_term easy understanding, num parameter added specify number returned records.

term <- c("Tp53", "Brca1", "Tet2")
keys <- c("stem cell", "mouse")
l <- getPubmed(term, keys)

## 2 PPR467733 PPR    <NA>     <NA>     10.1‚Ä¶ "Bia‚Ä¶ Ohno T, Aka‚Ä¶ <NA>         <NA> 
## 3 35435331  MED    35435331 PMC9189‚Ä¶ 10.1‚Ä¶ "Ide‚Ä¶ Thirouard L‚Ä¶ Adv Sci (We‚Ä¶ 17   
## 4 35536873  MED    35536873 <NA>     10.1‚Ä¶ "Com‚Ä¶ Liu T, Zhao‚Ä¶ Cancer Res   <NA>

## #   journalIssn <chr>, pageInfo <chr>, pubType <chr>, isOpenAccess <chr>,
## #   inEPMC <chr>, inPMC <chr>, hasPDF <chr>, hasBook <chr>, hasSuppl <chr>,
## #   citedByCount <int>, hasReferences <chr>, hasTextMinedTerms <chr>,

heading: 4 Gene ID conversion
text: handled genomics analysis, may spend much time converting gene identifiers types.example, gene set enrichment analysis common omics downstream process mainly based MsigDb. According release note, since MSigDB 7.0, identifiers genes mapped HGNC approved Gene Symbol NCBI Gene ID annotations extracted Ensembl‚Äôs BioMart data service, updated MSigDB release latest available version Ensembl. Currently, MSigDB 7.5 updated human gene annotations Ensembl v105.Hence, id conversion help keeping update latest annotations.common gene id types symbol (e.g.¬†TP53),NCBI Entrez (e.g.¬†7157) Ensembl (e.g.¬†ENSG00000141510). ID conversion among different types common two main concerns: performance flexibility.

heading: 4.1 Current tools
text: Currently various tools available, however different methods drawbacks:biomaRt: R package frequently used access --date Ensembl database. access online database time built-parameters many.clusterProfiler: R package depends Bioconductor annotation packages extract NCBI gene. NCBI database updates every day Bioconductor package updates nearly every six months. Besides, supports 20 organisms user download load annotation data mapping.gProfiler: web server supports 40 types IDs 60 species. supports one--one conversion, example, user want convert gene symbol Entrez Ensembl, happen. Besides, output result convenient process.DAVID: web server interface user-friendly.UniProt: large protein database may support almost species user needs specify input id type converts protein id.GIDcon: web server covers human, mouse rat. User must seperates gene ids comma batch query. Five symbols take 8 secs convert.Considered problems, genekitr combines Ensembl NCBI database provide comprehensive result optimizes running speed.Also supports 195 vertebrate species, 120 plant species 2 bacteria species (see also session 1.1).

heading: 4.2 Basic usage
text: transId provides five arguments:id: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl), protein id (see also session 4.2) microarray id (see also session 5.1)id: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl), protein id (see also session 4.2) microarray id (see also session 5.1)transTo: conversion target type. User select one ‚Äúsymbol‚Äù, ‚Äúentrez‚Äù, ‚Äúensembl‚Äù ‚Äúuniprot‚Äù. Besides, abbreviation acceptable (e.g.¬†‚Äúens‚Äù fine ‚Äúensembl‚Äù ‚Äúen‚Äù raise error separate ‚Äúentrez‚Äù)transTo: conversion target type. User select one ‚Äúsymbol‚Äù, ‚Äúentrez‚Äù, ‚Äúensembl‚Äù ‚Äúuniprot‚Äù. Besides, abbreviation acceptable (e.g.¬†‚Äúens‚Äù fine ‚Äúensembl‚Äù ‚Äúen‚Äù raise error separate ‚Äúentrez‚Äù)org: organism name, default humanorg: organism name, default humanunique: TRUE FALSE (default). TRUE, returns one matched id.unique: TRUE FALSE (default). TRUE, returns one matched id.keepNA: TRUE FALSE (default). id matched one, keep .keepNA: TRUE FALSE (default). id matched one, keep .See human example , due NA removed, result order slightly different input id.want get order, can set keepNA = TRUE:want get one--one mapping, can set unique = TRUE result comprehensive information return:
code:
# human genes
id <- c("AKT3", "SSX6P", "FAKE_ID", "BCC7")
transId(id, transTo = "ens")##   input_id         ensembl
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 4     BCC7 ENSG00000141510
# fruit fly genes
transId(
  id = c("10178780", "10178777", "10178786", "10178792"),
  transTo = "sym", org = "fly"
)##   input_id          symbol
## 1 10178780         CR33929
## 2 10178777         CG42835
## 3 10178786 Su(Ste):CR40820
## 4 10178792         CG42694
transId(id, transTo = "ens", keepNA = TRUE)##   input_id         ensembl
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 4  FAKE_ID            <NA>
## 5     BCC7 ENSG00000141510
transId(id, transTo = "ens", keepNA = TRUE, unique = TRUE)##    input_id         ensembl
## 21     AKT3 ENSG00000117020
## 1     SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 2   FAKE_ID            <NA>
## 3      BCC7 ENSG00000141510

heading: 4.3.1 f1: convert to several types
text: transTo accepts one type:
code:
transId(id, transTo = c("ens", "ent"))##   input_id         ensembl entrezid
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199    10000
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020    10000
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483   280657
## 4     BCC7 ENSG00000141510     7157

heading: 4.3.2 f2: distinguish from symbol and alias
text: One big common problem current tools confusion gene symbol gene alias.Gene alias alternative name official gene symbol, like ‚ÄúBCC7‚Äù actually alias ‚ÄúTP53‚Äù. Sometimes gene alias widely used official symbol. example, ‚ÄúPDL1‚Äù alias ‚ÄúCD274‚Äù fact.Due combination NCBI Ensembl metadata, transId easily recognize gene symbol alias setting transTo = 'symbol'.
code:
transId(c("BCC7", "TP53", "PD1", "PDL1", "TET2"), "sym")##   input_id symbol
## 1     BCC7   TP53
## 2     TP53   TP53
## 3      PD1  PDCD1
## 4      PD1   SNCA
## 5      PD1 SPATA2
## 6     PDL1  CD274
## 7     TET2   TET2

heading: 4.3.3 f3: no worry for Ensembl version
text:
Ensembl stable ID consists five parts: ENS(species)(object type)(identifier). (version)
example, ENSG00000141510.11 TP53 version .11 may confuse many tools.
However using transId, user worry issue .
code:
transId("ENSG00000141510.11", "symbol")##          input_id symbol
## 1 ENSG00000141510   TP53

heading: 5.2 Id conversion
text: convert protein id gene symbol compare original one.Maybe noticed gene names different original data. example, second one: A0JPQ8 called Alkmo , latest name Agmo.proteins new gene names like , may names now.see result : protein id P01835 replaced gene name NA.Venn plot shows primary protein ids changed gene names. users continue use old gene names, may lose latest gene information even enriched pathways.
code:
protein_id <- rat_prodata[, "Acc"]

heading: 6 Probe ID conversion
text: Probes used measure expression level many genes. getting micro array data, first important thing downstream analysis maybe probe id conversion.Ensembl database regularly maps probes sets latest set transcript models using pipeline., transProbe utilizes Ensembl --date annotation datasets join together genekitr functions fluently.Notice: now support human data

heading: 7 ORA GO analysis
text: paper ‚ÄúUrgent need consistent standards functional enrichment analysis‚Äù mentioned, popular functional enrichment tools can classified two main categories: (1) -representation analysis (ORA) (2) functional class scoring (FCS) .According paper ‚Äú-representation correlation analysis (ORCA): method identifying associations variable sets‚Äù:-representation analysis (ORA) simple method objectively deciding whether set variables known suspected biological relevance, gene set pathway, prevalent set variables interest expect chance.ORA usually procedures:Identify features, mRNA, proteins microarray probes, considered ‚Äúdifferentially expressed‚Äù two conditionsDetermine number differentially expressed features pathwayFor pathway, using hypergeometric distribution calculate probability value ( P -value) obtaining number differentially expressed features background list features

heading: 7.1 GO intruduction
text:
According Wikipedia, ‚ÄúOntologies consist detectable directly observable representations things relationships things.‚ÄùGO short Gene Ontology. GO analysis find associations gene products GO termsÔºå three domains:Biological Processes (BP)
biological process represents specific objective organism genetically programmed achieve.
biological process represents specific objective organism genetically programmed achieve.Molecular Functions (MF)
molecular process can carried action single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions molecular entities.
molecular process can carried action single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions molecular entities.Cellular Components (CC)
location, relative cellular compartments structures, occupied macromolecular machine carries molecular function.
location, relative cellular compartments structures, occupied macromolecular machine carries molecular function.GO terms built directed acyclic graph parent-child relationship.comprehensive introduction GO, may visit: https://advaitabio.com/faq-items/understanding-gene-ontology/ http://geneontology.org/docs/ontology-documentation/

heading: 7.2 Basic usage
text:
genGO built clusterProfiler::enrichGO optimizes analysis process make better understanding.simplest arguments :id: gene id entrez (numeric id also supported), ensembl, symbol (alias also accepted) uniprotorg: organism (genekitr::biocOrg_name)ont: ontology ‚Äúbp‚Äù, ‚Äúmf‚Äù, ‚Äúcc‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄùpvalueCutoffqvalueCutoffIf user proteomics data, protein IDs directly GO analysis instead gene conversion.
use data : rat protein example dataExcept GO enrichment result, protein IDs also mapped gene symbols easy understanding.

heading: 7.2.1 Additional arguments
text: pAdjustMethod: choose ‚Äúholm‚Äù, ‚Äúhochberg‚Äù, ‚Äúhommel‚Äù, ‚Äúbonferroni‚Äù, ‚ÄúBH‚Äù, ‚Äú‚Äù, ‚Äúfdr‚Äù, ‚Äúnone‚ÄùminGSSize: Minimal size gene set analysis. Default 10. Pathway less ten genes omitted (e.g.¬†GO:0062196 child term 8-gene bottom directed acyclic graph).maxGSSize: Maximal size. Default 500. pathway 500 genes omitted (e.g.¬†GO:0007049 1796 genes parent nodes top directed acyclic graph).universe: uses background genes, set universe. Otherwise, program take genes orgDb annotation package (e.g.¬†org.Hs.eg.db).

heading: 7.2.2 New features
text:
input id symbol, genGO convert symbol easy understanding. Besides, input id mixture gene symbol alias, result convert alias symbol automatically result show two columns geneID geneID_symbol. input id symbol result geneID, means input symbol alias.need sepcify input id type, genGO allocate automatically.genGO sets four measurement aspects: ‚ÄúCount‚Äù, ‚ÄúGeneRatio‚Äù, ‚ÄúFoldEnrichment‚Äù ‚ÄúRichFactor‚Äù.
Bg Ratio: Total number specific pathway gene/ Universal gene numbers (e.g., human protein-coding genes)
Gene Ratio: Genes interest specific pathway/gene interest (e.g., differentially expressed genes)
Fold Enrichment: GeneRatio / BgRatio
Rich Factor: Genes interest specific pathway/ Total number specific pathway gene
Bg Ratio: Total number specific pathway gene/ Universal gene numbers (e.g., human protein-coding genes)Gene Ratio: Genes interest specific pathway/gene interest (e.g., differentially expressed genes)Fold Enrichment: GeneRatio / BgRatioRich Factor: Genes interest specific pathway/ Total number specific pathway geneReturn data frame format easy select export interested pathways

simGO utilizes GOSemSim::goSim() calculate semantic similarity two GO terms, passes rrvgo::reduceSimMatrix() reduce redundant terms.Methods calculating similarity nodes: ‚ÄúResnik‚Äù, ‚ÄúLin‚Äù, ‚ÄúRel‚Äù, ‚ÄúJiang‚Äù , ‚ÄúWang‚Äù ‚ÄúJC‚Äù (Jaccard similarity coefficient).Let‚Äôs look terms considered redundant:

heading: 7.5.1 genGO vs enrichGO
text: input id contains gene alias, genGO invoke transId automatically convert gene alias symbol better explanation.check two results, may find clustp_res contains two genes: TET2 BRCA1, genekitr_res includes five genes.look deeper, may find six terms unique clustp_res, GO:0016571:Question1: terms omited genGO result?get adjusted p value, critical parameter number testing. simple explaination, adj.p = f * p (f>1) f related testing methods number tests.example, genGO recognizes five genes need five testings enrichGO includes two genes testing number less. directly causes adj.Pvalue ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù terms becomes higher filtered cutoff 0.01.set cutoff higher(e.g.¬†0.05), still get terms:Question2: enrichGO recognize two genes?gene ‚ÄúBCC7‚Äù, ‚ÄúPD1‚Äù ‚ÄúPDL1‚Äù essential must related pathways.core reason actually gene aliases enrichGO set argument keyType = "SYMBOL" cause enrichGO accepts official symbols. function based organism annotation package (e.g.¬†org.Hs.eg.db) accepts different types data:specifying keyType = 'ALIAS', program recognize gene alias, however still distinguish mixture symbol alias.
code:
check_gene <- c("BCC7", "PDL1", "PD1", "TET2", "BRCA1")

genekitr_res <- genekitr::genGO(check_gene, ont = "bp", org = "hs", 
                                pvalueCutoff = 0.01, qvalueCutoff = 0.01)

clustp_res <- clusterProfiler::enrichGO(check_gene,
  OrgDb = "org.Hs.eg.db",
  keyType = "SYMBOL",
  pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
  qvalueCutoff = 0.01,
  ont = "BP"
) %>% as.data.frame()

text:
KEGG short ‚ÄúKyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes,‚Äù collection databases dealing genomes, biological pathways, diseases, drugs, chemical substances.pathway maps classified following sections:MetabolismGenetic information processing (transcription, translation, replication repair, etc.)Environmental information processing (membrane transport, signal transduction, etc.)Cellular processes (cell growth, cell death, cell membrane functions, etc.)Organismal systems (immune system, endocrine system, nervous system, etc.)Human diseasesDrug development

heading: 8.3 Group enrichment

heading: 8.3.2 Comparison with more than one group:
text: additional arguments refer GO analysis.

id2 <- c(head(names(geneList), 100), tail(names(geneList), 100))
group2 <- list(
  group1 = c(rep("up", 100), rep("down", 100)),
  group2 = c(rep("A", 130), rep("B", 70))
)
gkeg <- genKEGG(id2,
  group_list = group2,
  org = "human",
  pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
  qvalueCutoff = 0.05
)

heading: 10 Functional Class Scoring
text: ORA method easy conduct, lose information genes‚Äô differences slight. example, gene essential pathway low-expressed, filtered fold change cutoff.Unlike ORA, FCS tools set threshold differentially expressed genes. Instead, gives detected gene differential expression score evaluates whether scores positive negative expected chance gene set.According article ‚ÄúTen Years Pathway Analysis: Current Approaches Outstanding Challenges‚Äù:FCS approaches include GSEA, GlobalTest, sigPathway, SAFE, GSA, PADOG, PCOT2, FunCluster, SAM-GS, Category etc.Next, go popular Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) tool, uses FCS permutation approaches determine whether gene set significantly associated higher lower scores.

heading: 10.1 GSEA intruduction
text:
GSEA, user must ordered gene rank list (e.g., genes decreasing logFC order).Three steps GSEA:Calculate enrichment score (ES): represents amount genes set -represented either top bottom list. GSEA starts top ranked gene list calculate enrichment score. gene member candidate gene set, adds running sum. Otherwise, subtracts.Calculate enrichment score (ES): represents amount genes set -represented either top bottom list. GSEA starts top ranked gene list calculate enrichment score. gene member candidate gene set, adds running sum. Otherwise, subtracts.Estimate statistical significance ES: calculation done phenotypic-based permutation test order produce null distribution ES.Estimate statistical significance ES: calculation done phenotypic-based permutation test order produce null distribution ES.Adjust multiple hypothesis testing large number gene sets analyzed one time: enrichment scores set normalized, false discovery rate calculated.Adjust multiple hypothesis testing large number gene sets analyzed one time: enrichment scores set normalized, false discovery rate calculated.

IDs plot actually ID column kk_easy result. want add content, just modify ID column:

data(geneList, package="DOSE")
## GSEA result from clusterProfiler
kk <- gseKEGG(geneList     = geneList,
               organism     = 'hsa',
               minGSSize    = 120,
               pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
               verbose      = FALSE)

## import
kk_easy <- importCP(kk,type = 'gsea')
identical(kk@result[,1], kk_easy$gsea_df[,1])## [1] TRUE
plotGSEA(kk_easy, plot_type = "bar",
         main_text_size = 15)
kk_easy$gsea_df$ID <- paste(kk_easy$gsea_df$ID, kk_easy$gsea_df$Description,sep = ": ")
plotGSEA(kk_easy, plot_type = "bar",
         main_text_size = 15)

heading: 11.2.3 clusterProfiler KEGG/DOSE/WikiPathways‚Ä¶ result
text:
clusterProfiler supports many gene sets, including Disease Ontology (), WikiPathways, ReactomePATake example:select interested terms utilize plot functions Chapter 11.example:
Figure 11.6: Heatmap clusterProfiler result.
code:
library(DOSE)
data(geneList)
gene <- names(geneList)[abs(geneList) > 1.5]

## ORA-DO result from clusterProfiler
do <- enrichDO(gene          = gene,
              ont           = "DO",
              pvalueCutoff  = 0.05,
              pAdjustMethod = "BH",
              universe      = names(geneList),
              minGSSize     = 5,
              maxGSSize     = 500,
              qvalueCutoff  = 0.05)

# import
do_easy <- importCP(do,type = 'other')
identical(as.data.frame(do)[,1], do_easy[,1])## [1] TRUE
plotEnrich(do_easy, 
           plot_type = "geneheat",
           fold_change = geneList,
           show_gene = c('S100A9','AGTR1','BIRC5','MMP1','CXCL10'))

heading: 12 Plot GO and KEGG
text: selecting interested terms pathways genGO genKEGG result, user pass data frame plotEnrich, includes many ready-made plot types GO KEGG result, including barplot, dotplot, heatmap, wego-like plot, chord plot, network, wordcloud etc.worth mentioning almost plots based ggplot2 plot_theme function easily change border, legend, label etc., helps user make plot.

heading: 12.1 GO/KEGG: Bar Plot
text:
Bar plot simplest way show enriched terms. x-axis enrichment metric (e.g.¬†Gene ratio; Fold enrichment); y-axis selected terms. bar color represents statistical value.‚Äôs difference pvalue p.adjust?
p.adjust seven adjustment methods: https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/stats/versions/3.5.0/topics/p.adjust.
adjusted p-value always p-value, multiplied factor: adj.p = f * p actual size factor f depends strategy used correct multiple testing.
way, ‚Äúq-value‚Äù stands ‚Äúfalse discovery rate (FDR)‚Äù method.basic arguments :term_metric: x-axis ‚ÄúCount‚Äù, ‚ÄúGeneRatio‚Äù, ‚ÄúFoldEnrich‚Äù ‚ÄúRichFactor‚Äùstats_metric: Statistic value ‚Äúp.adjust‚Äù, ‚Äúpvalue‚Äù ‚Äúqvalue‚Äùup_color: Color stronger statistic value (e.g.¬†pvalue 0.01)down_color: Color weaker statistic value (e.g.¬†pvalue 1)wrap_length: Wrap term text longer number
Figure 12.1: Bar plot enrichment analysis. default (), modify metrics (B), modify color (C) modify term length (D).
code:
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
id <- names(geneList)[abs(geneList) > 1.5]
logfc <- geneList[id]

ego <- genGO(id,
  org = "human", ont = "bp", pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
  qvalueCutoff = 0.01
)
# Here just show top ten terms, you can choose your own interested terms!
ego <- ego[1:10, ]
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bar")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bar", term_metric = "GeneRatio", stats_metric = "pvalue")
p3 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bar", up_color = "#E69056", down_color = "#325CAC")
p4 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bar", wrap_length = 25)
p1 + p2 + p3 + p4 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.2 GO/KEGG: Bubble Plot
text:
Enriched gene sets shown bubbles different sizes.x-axis statistic value y-axis ‚ÄúFold Enrichment‚Äù.basic arguments :stats_metric: Statistic value ‚Äúp.adjust‚Äù, ‚Äúpvalue‚Äù ‚Äúqvalue‚Äùscale_ratio: Change bubble size. Default 1.
Figure 12.2: Bubble plot enrichment analysis. default (), modify bubble size (B).
code:
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bubble")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "bubble", 
                 scale_ratio = 0.5, stats_metric = "qvalue")
p1 / p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.3 GO/KEGG: Dot Plot
text:
Similar bar plot, dot plot also widely used enrichment analysis plotting. Like bubble plot, dot size represents gene number enriched term.
Figure 12.3: Dot plot enrichment analysis. default (), modify bubble size (B).
analyzing group enrichment analysis GO KEGG, use dotplot show result:
Figure 12.4: Dot plot group enrichment analysis. number round brackets shows total gene number selected pathways
code:
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "dot")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego,
  plot_type = "dot",
  scale_ratio = 1.5,
  stats_metric = "pvalue",
  term_metric = "RichFactor"
)
p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")
plotEnrich(gego2,
           plot_type = 'dot',
           scale_ratio = 2, # dot size
           main_text_size = 10,
           legend_text_size =8,
           n_term = 6) # show terms

heading: 12.4 GO: WEGO Plot
text:
user analyzed one ontology, may want show one figure.
Inspired WEGO, genekitr utilized ggplot2 reproduce plot.generate three ontologies (BP,MF CC) result.just want show two ontologies, can rbind dataframes give new dataframe new column ‚ÄúONTOLOGY‚Äù distinguish different ontologies.NOTICE: plotEnrich parameter n_term WEGO plot, specify number terms. want plot terms, just set n_term higher.
Figure 12.5: WEGO plot enrichment analysis.

heading: 12.5 GO/KEGG: Lollipop Plot
text:
Lollipop like combination barplot dotplot
Figure 12.6: Lollipop plot enrichment analysis. defult (), selected genes (B)
code:
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "lollipop")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego,
  plot_type = "lollipop",
  scale_ratio = 1.2,
  stats_metric = "pvalue",
  term_metric = "RichFactor",
  up_color = "#a32a31",
  down_color = "#f7dcca"
)
p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.6 GO/KEGG: Heatmap Plot
text:
Heatmap plot shows interactions enriched terms genes.
fold change given, heatmap add color -regulated genes.
Figure 12.7: Heatmap plot enrichment analysis. genes (, default), selected genes (B), selected genes logFC value (C).
code:
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "geneheat")
show_gene <- c("BRCA2", "CDK1", "JUN", "MCM8", "TIPIN")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "geneheat", show_gene = show_gene)
p3 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "geneheat", show_gene = show_gene, fold_change = logfc)
p1 / p2 / p3 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.7 GO/KEGG: Chord Plot
text:
Inspired GOplot, chord plot reproduced using ggplot2 shows similar content heatmap plot.gene_space: space gene labels chord.
Figure 12.8: Heatmap plot enrichment analysis. selected genes (), selected genes logFC value (B).
code:
library(patchwork)
show_gene <- c("BRCA2", "CDK1", "JUN", "MCM8", "TIPIN")
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "genechord", 
                 show_gene = show_gene) +
  ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "genechord", 
                 show_gene = show_gene, 
                 fold_change = logfc,
                 gene_space = 0.5)
p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.8 GO/KEGG: Wordcloud Plot
text:
Wordcloud plot shows term emphasis based text frequency.
Figure 12.9: Wordcloud plot enrichment analysis.
code: plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "wordcloud")

heading: 12.9 GO/KEGG: Upset Plot
text:
Inspired ComplexUpset, upset plot shows association genes enriched terms. Unlike common Venn diagram, emphasize complex relationship among many gene sets.
Figure 12.10: Upset plot enrichment analysis.
code: plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "upset",main_text_size = 15,legend_text_size = 8)

heading: 12.10 GO/KEGG: Network Plot
text:
Inspired enrichplot::emapplot, genekitr reproduced plot enhance modification.
Enriched terms nodes network, overlapping gene sets edges. Terms overlapped genes tend cluster together edge thicker.GO analysis result use five methods calculate similarity nodes: ‚ÄúResnik‚Äù, ‚ÄúLin‚Äù, ‚ÄúRel‚Äù, ‚ÄúJiang‚Äù, ‚ÄúWang‚Äù ‚ÄúJC‚Äù(Jaccard‚Äôs similarity index) methods.KEGG supports ‚ÄúJC‚Äù method.User define layout argument derived ggraph, including ‚Äúnicely‚Äù (default), ‚Äúcircle‚Äù, ‚Äúdh‚Äù, ‚Äúdrl‚Äù, ‚Äúfr‚Äù, ‚Äúgraphopt‚Äù, ‚Äúgrid‚Äù,‚Äúlgl‚Äù, ‚Äúkk‚Äù, ‚Äúmds‚Äù, ‚Äúrandomly‚Äù, ‚Äústar‚Äù etc.information layout, refer : ‚ÄúIntroduction ggraph: Layouts‚Äù
Figure 12.11: Network plot enrichment analysis. JC method nicely layout(, default), circle layout (B), grid layout Want method (C).
code:
library(patchwork)
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "network", scale_ratio = 0.5)
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "network", 
                 layout = "circle", scale_ratio = 0.5)
p3 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "network", 
                 layout = "grid", sim_method = "Wang",
                 up_color = "#a32a31", down_color = "#f7dcca")
(p1 + p2) / p3 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.11 GO: Map Plot
text:
GO terms built directed acyclic graph parent-child relationship.
map plot utilized GOSemSim extract parent child terms, also utilized ggraph igraph draw default layout ‚Äúsugiyama‚Äù.avoid much unrelated terms messed , genekitr shows closest parent child selected terms. Besides, top three parent term edges plotted.
Figure 12.12: Map plot enrichment analysis.
code:
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "gomap", wrap_length = 25,
           up_color = '#a32a31',down_color = '#3665a6')

heading: 12.12 GO: Terms Heatmap Plot
text:
Inspired rrvgo, genekitr scratches main codes cluster GO terms. Also use five methods calculate similarity terms.
Figure 12.13: GO heatmap plot enrichment analysis.
code: plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "goheat", sim_method = "Rel")

heading: 12.13 GO: Terms Tangram Plot
text:
According rrvgo vignettes, tangram plot space-filling visualization hierarchical structures. terms grouped colored based parent, space used term proportional score.
Figure 12.14: GO tangram plot enrichment analysis.
code: plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "gotangram", sim_method = "Rel")

heading: 12.14 Plot Theme
text:
Genekitr provides function plot_theme() modify plots theme including text size, border, legend, color, etc.
Figure 12.15: Plot theme. default theme (), modify text size (B), modify grid line border size (C) remove text legend (D).
code:
library(patchwork)
p1 <- plotEnrich(ego, plot_type = "dot")
p2 <- plotEnrich(ego,
  plot_type = "dot",
  main_text_size = 10,
  legend_text_size = 10
)

p3 <- plotEnrich(ego,
  plot_type = "dot",
  border_thick = 3,
  remove_grid = F
)

p4 <- plotEnrich(ego,
  plot_type = "dot",
  remove_main_text = T,
  remove_legend_text = T,
  remove_legend = T
)
p1 + p2 + p3 + p4 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 12.15.1 Two-group barplot for up/down regulated pathways
text:
user genGO genKEGG regulated genes separately wants visualize together, two-group barplot well suited. take GO result example:two visulization types:plot_type = "one": -regulated pathways plotted togetherplot_type = "two": -regulated pathways plotted separately. Recommended number groups similar.
Figure 12.16: Visualize two groups together plot_type = "one".

Figure 12.17: Visualize two groups seperately plot_type = "two".
code:
# Since the geneList is logFC decreasing ordered, we could take first 100 as up-regulated genes and vice versa.
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
up_genes <- head(names(geneList), 100)
down_genes <- tail(names(geneList), 100)

up_go <- genGO(up_genes,
               org = "human", 
               ont = "bp", 
               pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
               qvalueCutoff = 0.05
)

down_go <- genGO(down_genes,
                 org = "human", 
                 ont = "bp", 
                 pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
                 qvalueCutoff = 0.01
)

dim(up_go)## [1] 62 12
dim(down_go)## [1] 114  12
# seems that up/down-regulated pathways are too many, here we only take 10 of them
up_go <- head(up_go, 10)
down_go <- head(down_go, 10)
plotEnrichAdv(up_go, down_go,
              plot_type = "one",
              term_metric = "FoldEnrich",
              stats_metric = "p.adjust",
              xlim_left = 25, xlim_right = 15) +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.15, 0.9))
plotEnrichAdv(up_go, down_go,
              plot_type = "two",
              term_metric = "FoldEnrich",
              stats_metric = "qvalue"
)

heading: 13 Plot GSEA
text: GSEA analysis returns list result, directly passed plotGSEA. function help draw classic pathway plot, volcano plot, multi-pathway plot, ridge plot two-side bar plot.
code:
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
gse <- genGSEA(
  genelist = geneList, 
  org = "human",
  category = "H", 
  pvalueCutoff = 0.05
)

heading: 13.1 Classic Pathway Plot
text:
Running enrichment score gene set drawn classic pathway plot lines. function walks ranked gene list. vertical lines middle show location gene set members.user wants show specific pathways genes, just pass according parameters: show_pathway show_gene.
Figure 13.1: Classic pathway plot GSEA.
code:
pathways <- c("HALLMARK_P53_PATHWAY", "HALLMARK_GLYCOLYSIS", "HALLMARK_DNA_REPAIR")
genes <- c("MET", "TP53", "PMM2")
plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "classic", show_pathway = pathways, show_gene = genes)

heading: 13.2 Volcano Pathway Plot
text:
plot, degree enrichment indicated normalized enrichment score NES.Slightly different DEG volcano plot, x-axis represented NES, corrects enrichment score differences among gene-sets.significant positive NES value indicates members gene set tend appear top ranked data (e.g.¬†fold change DEG) significant negative NES indicates opposite.Default shows top(N) pathways. user wants show specific pathway, also pass argument show_pathway.
Figure 13.2: Volcano pathway plot GSEA. default (), select pathways (B).
code:
library(patchwork)
pathways <- c("HALLMARK_P53_PATHWAY", "HALLMARK_GLYCOLYSIS", "HALLMARK_DNA_REPAIR")
p1 <- plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "volcano", show_pathway = 3)
p2 <- plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "volcano", show_pathway = pathways)
p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 13.3 Multi-pathway Plot
text:
user wants show bunch selected pathways, plotGSEA scratched codes fgsea.Default shows top(N) pathways. user wants show specific pathway, also pass argument show_pathway.
Figure 13.3: Multi-pathway plot GSEA. default (), select pathways (B).
code:
library(patchwork)
pathways <- c("HALLMARK_P53_PATHWAY", "HALLMARK_GLYCOLYSIS", "HALLMARK_DNA_REPAIR")
p1 <- plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "fgsea", show_pathway = 5)
p2 <- plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "fgsea", show_pathway = pathways)
p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")

heading: 13.4 Ridge Plot
text:
Ridge plot visualize enriched pathways /regulated genes. x-axis fold change y-axis pathways. Color represents statistical value (e.g.¬†pvalue/p.adjust/qvalue)
Figure 13.4: Ridge plot GSEA.
code:
plotGSEA(gse,
  plot_type = "ridge",
  show_pathway = 10, stats_metric = "p.adjust"
)

heading: 13.5 Two-side Barplot
text:
barplot separate positive negative NES two sides. User specify color two sides. Meanwhile, non-significant pathways (e.g.¬†Pvalue > 0.05) colored ‚Äúgrey‚Äù.
Figure 13.5: Two-side bar plot GSEA.
code: plotGSEA(gse, plot_type = "bar", colour = c("navyblue", "orange"))

heading: 14 Plot others
text: part, introduce plotVenn plotVolcano.

heading: 14.1 Venn Plot
text:
Venn plot needs list gene sets, example:plotVenn supports two types: Venn (default) UpSet. Besides, also supports modification text size, alpha degree, colors parameters plot_theme.
Figure 14.1: Venn plot
UpSet plot better four groups genes:
Figure 14.2: UpSet plot
code:
set1 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set2 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set3 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set4 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))
set5 <- paste0(rep("gene", 100), sample(1:1000, 100))

# three groups
sm_gene_list <- list(gset1 = set1, gset2 = set2, gset3 = set3)

# five groups
la_gene_list <- list(
  gset1 = set1, gset2 = set2, gset3 = set3,
  gset4 = set4, gset5 = set5
)
plotVenn(sm_gene_list,
         use_venn = TRUE,
         color = ggsci::pal_lancet()(3),
         alpha_degree = 1,
         main_text_size = 1.5,
         border_thick = 0
)
plotVenn(la_gene_list,
         use_venn = FALSE,
         main_text_size = 15,
         legend_text_size = 8,
         legend_position = 'left'
)

heading: 14.2 Volcano Plot
text:
finishing differential expression analysis, get differentially expressed genes (DEG).
Volcano plot widely used /regulated genes visualization.example data micro array differential expression analysis:plotVolcano mainly uses DEG result include gene id, fold change statistic value.also parameters:stat_metric: choose ‚Äúpvalue‚Äù ‚Äúp.adjust‚Äùstat_cutoff: cutoff significant statistic value, default 0.05logFC_cutoff: cutoff log2 (fold change), default 1 actually two fold changesup_color: color -regulated genesdown_color: color -regulated genesshow_gene: show gene names, default none. Suggest renaming column genes ‚Äúgene‚Äù.dot_size: volcano dot size
Figure 14.3: Volcano plot
want show genes:
Figure 14.4: Volcano plot genes.
Trick increasing text size:User hide x/y-axis labels raise main_text_size enlarge gene text, export figure PPT add labels.
